Facilities and Construction Management                                                             New York University - Facilities and Construction Management                       Throughout 2013, New York University’s Facilities and Construction Management (FCM) department staff have intensified their efforts to prepare for the NYU-Poly merger, and assumption of responsibilities for the operation, maintenance and construction of NYU-Poly’s facilities, including assigning , FCM staff to assist with managing construction projects in Brooklyn.   Within the new year, FCM will continue to partner with Dennis Dintino (VP, Finance & Business Affairs) and Danny Aniello (Director, Administration) as continues. In the new year, the responsibilities of the Director of Facilities and Construction Management for the NYU School of Engineering and all Brooklyn locations will be assumed by James (Jim) Burgess. Jim will be working closely with the NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering facilities service staff and facilities management staff assigned to the school, to ensure the facilities are functioning optimally to serve the academic mission of the University and the NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering. We look forward to welcoming the integrated NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering facilities service and engineering staff into the FCM department.   New York University’s Facilities and Construction Management (FCM) department is staffed by numerous credentialed professionals who have subject matter expertise in a wide variety of facilities and construction-related fields (construction, engineering, architecture, etc.) A brief summary of the services provided by FCM are as follows:      Construction – space planning, project management, and compliance www.nyu.edu/construction    Facilities – building services, building management, compliance, maintenance and operations www.nyu.edu/fcm    Health and Safety – workplace safety, environmental regulatory compliance, and fire & life safety www.nyu.edu/ehs    Energy and Engineering – sustainability, energy management, energy acquisition, and facilities-related engineering www.nyu.edu/sustainability     For further information visit the NYU FCM websites listed above.   As the new year progresses, more detailed information will be made available, which describes the services provided by FCM and how to access the services provided by FCM.                                                        With the fast growth of urban population local governments, public service agencies, and urban utilities presently face increasing public demand for greater reliability, safety, affordability and resiliency of the aging urban infrastructure systems. These systems have to be continuously adapted and upgraded (often with technology-driven solutions) to efficiently support the essential public services, urban development and economic growth.   The infrastructure systems support a variety of urban sectors, including transportation, energy & water supply, sanitation & wastewater management, and other essential services. Their sustainable development engages a wide variety of public and private sector stakeholders and greatly depends on a broad range of factors, such as public policy objectives, land use and geo-physical system characteristics, regulatory requirements, and other variables. Both Government and Industry presently face increasing needs for innovative capabilities of dynamic monitoring and “smart” system control to effectively meet the challenge of upgrading the aging urban infrastructure systems.   With specialized faculty members from Government, Industry and Academia, the program is designed for professionals, with both engineering and non-engineering backgrounds, who are involved and/or interested in the fast growing inter-disciplinary field of urban systems management and career opportunities with government agencies, public and private sector utilities, and service industries across the wide array of the metropolitan sectors.   Admissions Requirements   This program is open to professionals with BS or BA degrees and backgrounds in engineering, science, public policy, management, economics, and/or finance. Necessary mathematics background, usually including undergraduate calculus, is required, as is an undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or better.   All applicants for this MS program must additionally show evidence of general quantitative analytic ability, including a minimum of 2 years of college mathematics and a college-level course in statistics.
